items.title: Toxic ions in chloride equivalents (eCl)
items.significance: High eCl indicates risk of water toxicity to plants. Used in Ukrainian standards.
items.interpretation: For sandy soils eCl <15 is good; 15–40 moderate. For loam: <10 good; 10–30 moderate. For clay: <5 good; 5–25 moderate.

items.title: Soluble Sodium Percentage (SSP)
items.significance: SSP reflects sodium dominance among cations. High SSP affects soil structure (sodification hazard) and infiltration.
items.interpretation: SSP > 60% is hazardous. Lower values are safer.

items.title: Stebler's alkaline coefficient (K)
items.significance: K reflects alkalinity risk from Na and carbonate relative to Ca/Mg.

items.title: Sodium Adsorption Ratio (SAR)
items.significance: SAR assesses sodicity hazard. High SAR leads to clay dispersion and poor permeability.
items.interpretation: SAR < 10: low risk; 10–18: moderate; >18: high risk.

items.title: Coefficient of Ion Exchange (CIE)
items.significance: CIE reflects the balance of flocculating (Ca/Mg) vs dispersing (Na) ions.
items.interpretation: CIE > 1: acceptable; CIE < 1: sodic hazard likely.

items.title: Residual Sodium Carbonate (RSC)
items.significance: High RSC indicates carbonate may reduce Ca/Mg, increasing Na dominance.

items.title: Kelly's Ratio (KR)
items.significance: KR > 1 suggests Na exceeds Ca + Mg — an indicator of sodic hazard.
items.interpretation: KR > 1: unsuitable; KR < 1: suitable for irrigation.
